crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects different hacktools based on their imphash
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the execution of different Windows based hacktools via their import hash (imphash) even if the files have been renamed
Detects the use of HandleKatz, a tool that demonstrates the usage of cloned handles to Lsass in order to create an obfuscated memory dump of the same

exiftool.ImageFileCharacteristics: No relocs, Executable, No line numbers, No symbols, Large address aware, No debug

attributes.magic: PE32+ executable (console) x86-64 (stripped to external PDB), for MS Windows

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: This binary is a specialized credential dumping tool known as 'HandleKatz.' It is designed to dump the memory of the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS) by cloning handles, a technique used to evade security products. The sample contains a hardcoded Base64-encoded shellcode payload in the 'main' function (address 0x401540), which is decoded via 'CryptStringToBinaryA', mapped into memory with 'PAGE_EXECUTE_READWRITE' via 'VirtualAlloc', and executed. Command-line arguments such as '--pid', '--recon', and '--outfile' confirm its functionality as a targeted memory dumper. The presence of strings referencing 'HandleKatz' and 'lsass' further validates its malicious use for credential harvesting.
